<misra_rule>

</misra_rule>
<instruction>

Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
add_response_entry (struct MHD_Response *response,
                    enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                    const char *header,
                    const char *content)
{
  size_t header_len;
  size_t content_len;

  if (NULL == content)
    return MHD_NO;

  header_len = strlen (header);
  content_len = strlen (content);
  return add_response_entry_n (response, kind, header,
                               header_len, content,
                               content_len) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only potential recursion risk in this function is the call to add_response_entry_n; investigators must check whether add_response_entry_n calls back to add_response_entry (directly or indirectly). There is no direct call to add_response_entry within this function body, so no direct recursion here. Other lines (NULL check for content, strlen calls, local size_t declarations, and the function signature itself) do not constitute function calls that could produce recursion and therefore do not need to be investigated for Rule 17.2. Inspect add_response_entry_n and any functions it calls to determine if an indirect recursive cycle exists.
